summary: ebolaviruses have a single-stranded RNA genome that encodes seven structural and two nonstructural proteins (44) the genome is encapsidated by the nucleoprotein (NP) and forms ribonucleoprotein complexes (RNPs) within virus particles, RNPs are found in the form of condensed nucleocapsids. inclusion bodies can be detected by light microscopy (2, 32, 43), fluorescence microscopy (28), and electron microscopy (2, 12, 13, 32, 33, 43) inclusion bodies contain nucleocapsids or nucleocapsid-like structures (12, 33, 35, 43, 46) inclusions are often regarded as a cellular mechanism to dispose of large quantities of misfolded proteins. virus infection, are the site of viral RNA synthesis (26) similar findings were also reported for another rhabdovirus, vesicular stomatitis virus (18). to this end, we generated a recombinant ZEBOV that expresses a fluorescently tagged polymerase. recombinant viruses were based on ZEBOV (strain Mayinga; accession number AF272001). all work with viruses was performed in the BSL-4 laboratories at the Philipps Universität Marburg, Germany. expression plasmids for the minigenome and viral proteins have been previously described. western blotting was performed as previously described 48 h after transfection. cells were visualized on an inverted Axiovert 200 M microscope. a minigenome assay 293T cells were transfected with expression plasmids carrying NP, VP35, VP30, and L. expression plasmids for VP40, VP24, and GP were cotransfected. this led to the formation of trVLPs, which contained minigenomes in form of RNP complexes. supernatant from these cells was clarified and stocks were frozen in liquid nitrogen.
